This way facilitates personalization and then alleviates conflicts arising from data heterogeneity in global model’s parameters.

S3.SS1.tab1.footnotes:
We compare FedLoRA/FedMem with several baselines:
(i) Public Model (P-S2T): a pre-trained S2T model provided by the server and used to initialize the client’s model.
(ii) Centralized Model (C-S2T): a standard centralized training method that uses all clients’ speech data to train a global S2T model.
It contains two versions, i.e., full fine-tuning and LoRA tuning.
(iii) FedAvg [11]: a vanilla FL approach which optimizes the global S2T model based on multi-round iterations with whole models.For the aforementioned settings, the clients utilize the pre-trained models (i.e., Conformer [15] or Whisper [14]) provided by the server for initialization. We pre-train Conformer on MuST-C [32] data in Table 3.1. It consists of 12 encoders and 6 decoders, with the embedding size, FFN size, and heads being 512, 2048, and 4, respectively. Each clients adopt an Adam with a learning rate of 1e-4 and 500 warm-up updates. We follow the Fairseq-S2T111https://github.com/facebookresearch/fairseq/blob/main/examples/speech_to_text
recipe to process the speech data, and use SentencePiece222https://github.com/google/sentencepiece
to build 10K/16K unigram sub-words for the English/Chinese text.
We also employ the Whisper-small to conduct experiment, where
each client’s learning rate and warm-up steps are set to 5e-5 and 1K, respectively. We add the LoRA module to the WQ,WK,WV,Wp​r​o​j,F​C1​and​F​C2subscript𝑊𝑄subscript𝑊𝐾subscript𝑊𝑉subscript𝑊𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑗𝐹subscript𝐶1and𝐹subscript𝐶2W_{Q},W_{K},W_{V},W_{proj},FC_{1}\text{and}\ FC_{2} of the self-attention and set rank/alpha 32/64 respectively. All training is conducted on 8 V100 GPUs. In each round of interaction, the client update epoch is set to 1, and the global patience is set to 5 to select the optimal rounds. FedMem employs the Faiss333https://github.com/facebookresearch/faiss
library to build the datastore and quantizes it into 4096 clusters using IndexIVFPQ, which can reduce storage and accelerate inference. During inference, the beam size is set to 5. When applying FedMem, we search 64 clusters for each target token. We search for the best k∈{4,8,16},λ∈{0.1,0.2,…,0.9}​and​T∈{10,20,50,100,200}formulae-sequence𝑘4816𝜆0.10.2…0.9and𝑇102050100200k\in\{4,8,16\},\lambda\in\{0.1,0.2,...,0.9\}\ \text{and}\ T\in\{10,20,50,100,200\} on the dev set. We evaluate ASR and ST using case-sensitive WER and SacreBLEU444https://github.com/mjpost/sacrebleu
, respectively.As illustrated in Table 1, the Whisper-based methods consistently outperform their Conformer-based counterparts.
Specifically, the Conformer-based FedAvg and FedLoRA are both worse than C-S2TFullFull{}_{\textsc{Full}}. In contrast, the Whisper-based FedLoRA exhibits superior performance compared to both C-S2TFullFull{}_{\textsc{Full}} and FedAvg. This improvement can be attributed to the fact that, with sufficient pre-training (Whisper employs 680k hours of speech data for pre-training), the lightweight LoRA component effectively overcomes catastrophic forgetting, enabling the preservation of pre-trained knowledge and the integration of client data.
Unlike the full model interaction of FedAvg, the lightweight LoRA component mitigates the impact of model parameter conflicts arising from data heterogeneity to some extent.
Moreover, considering that FedLoRA reduces the communication cost by 96.5%percent\% and 91.4%percent\% of FedAvg via lightweight LoRA module update and interaction, collectively FedLoRA is efficient and effective. Furthermore, FedMem enhances all FL methods, outperforms C-S2TFullFull{}_{\textsc{Full}} by 0.61 WER on average in Whisper-based methods. This indicates that client-specific memorization retrieval can be effective in personalizing the global model to further overcome the data heterogeneity.For the ST task, we observe similar trends as ASR task from Table 3.
Specifically, in comparison to the C-S2T, the performance of FedAvg and FedLoRA are negatively affected by data heterogeneity.
FedLoRA effectively reduces the communication cost by 95.5% of of that incurred by FedAvg. Furthermore, when FedMem is adopted, the average BLEU scores of FedAvg/FedLoRA are improved by 0.38/0.52, respectively. This demonstrates the efficiency and effectiveness of our approach on the ST task.To evaluate the scalability of our approach in a large-scale client setting, we conducted experiments using the multi-domain Gigaspeech ASR benchmark, which inherently exhibits a higher degree of data heterogeneity. As depicted in Table 4, we observed that FedLoRA significantly surpasses FedAvg by an average of 0.73 WER, while concurrently reducing the communication cost by 91.7%. Moreover, when integrated with FedMem, the average performance of FedLoRA is notably superior to both C-S2TFullFull{}_{\textsc{Full}} and C-S2TLoRALoRA{}_{\textsc{LoRA}}, with improvements of 0.69/0.53 WER, respectively. These results demonstrate that our proposed method exhibits high scalability in large-scale, highly heterogeneous federated learning settings.To evaluate the generalization ability to new coming clients, we conduct experiments on 6 ”training-invisible” clients of multi-domain benchmark.
In these experiments, FedMem directly utilize the global models FedAvg and FedLoRA to establish a datastore and equip k𝑘kNN for memorization retrieval during inference.
The results, as shown in Table 5, indicate that FedLoRA outperforms C-S2T and achieves similar performance to FedAvg, suggesting that FedLoRA can effectively generalize to new clients. Furthermore, compared to FedAvg/FedLoRA, FedMem achieves an average improvement of 0.65/0.67 WER scores, respectively. This implies that newly arriving clients can easily learn personalized systems after global training.Communication Cost.
When interacting for r𝑟r rounds between a server and |C|𝐶|C| clients, the communication costs for FedAvg and FedLoRA are, respectively,
Hθ∗|C|+Hθ∗|C|∗r∗2subscript𝐻𝜃𝐶subscript𝐻𝜃𝐶𝑟2H_{\theta}*|C|+H_{\theta}*|C|*r*2 and Hθ∗|C|+Hδ∗|C|∗r∗2subscript𝐻𝜃𝐶subscript𝐻𝛿𝐶𝑟2H_{\theta}*|C|+H_{\delta}*|C|*r*2,
where Hθ​and​Hδsubscript𝐻𝜃andsubscript𝐻𝛿H_{\theta}\ \text{and}\ H_{\delta} indicate the hard disk storage of the backbone model and the LoRA module. Typically, Hδsubscript𝐻𝛿H_{\delta} is much smaller than Hθsubscript𝐻𝜃H_{\theta}. As the number of clients and rounds increase, FedLoRA requires a lower communication load compared to FedAvg. In our experiments, FedLoRA approach reduce the communication cost by least to 91.4%percent91.491.4\% compared to FedAvg, making it more scalable for large-scale settings.Inference Overhead.
The inference overhead of k𝑘kNN memorization retrieval has been discussed in previous work [24, 31], which may slightly reduce the speed. In this work, we investigate it on the CoVoST ASR benchmark based on Conformer. By setting the batch size and k𝑘k to 16 and 8, respectively, we find that the average inference speed of FedMem across four dialects is 92.9%percent92.992.9\% of that of the C-S2T. In practice, such a decline is acceptable, as it represents a trade-off between performance and processing time. We could also substitute it with other memorization-retrieval variants [29, 30, 31] to achieve better inference speed, we leave it as future work.In this paper, we present the first personalized federated S2T framework. We first design FedLoRA to leverage a lightweight LoRA module to reduce communication overhead. Then FedMem employs client-specific memorization retrieval for personalization to address data heterogeneity. Experimental results on various FL scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of our framework.
In the future, we would like to integrate our methods with large S2T models (e.g., Whisper-Large) and explore more memorization retrieval methods.We thank the anonymous reviewers for helpful feedback on early versions of this work.
This work was supported by the grants from National Natural Science Foundation of China (No.62222213, 62072423), the Stable Support Project of National Defense Science and Technology Key Laboratory of State Administration of Science and Technology Industry (WDZC20245250113), and the USTC Research Funds of the Double First-Class Initiative (No.YD2150002009). Zhirui and Tong are the corresponding authors.

references:
We adopt two federated S2T scenarios to conduct experiments, in which natural data exists heterogeneity: i) dialect setting, which uses four accents from the CoVoST [18] benchmarks (English ASR and English-Chinese ST) as the four clients. ii) multi-domain setting, which uses ten domains from the GigaSpeech [19] benchmark (English ASR) as the clients involved in FL training.
The additional six domains as invisible clients to investigate the test-time generalization ability.
Table 3.1 details the statistics of these datasets.
